title: 115_s62
content: The Act may be cited as the "January 8th National Memorial Act". Congress found that the tragedy on January 8, 2011, at Congresswoman Gabrielle Gifford's event resulted in the deaths of 6 people and injuries to 13 others, including Giffords herself. It was the first assassination attempt on a Congressional Member during a constituent meeting. Giffords sustained severe injuries that still affect her today. Gabe Zimmerman was the first Congressional staffer involved. The Arizona community united after the assassination of Gabe Zimmerman, the first Congressional staffer to be killed in the line of duty. Three memorial sites were established to honor the victims and show support. The Tucson January 8th Memorial will commemorate the tragedy and the global response to it. The Tucson January 8th Memorial is a place where visitors can learn about the resilience of a community and democracy in the United States. The Tucson January 8th Memorial is a place where visitors can learn about the resilience of a community and democracy in the United States. SEC. 3. JANUARY 8\TH\ NATIONAL MEMORIAL. The January 8th National Memorial, established by the Secretary of the Interior, is affiliated with the National Park System. Key definitions include the Memorial, Foundation, Map, and Secretary. The Memorial, affiliated with the National Park System, shall not be established until the Foundation sets up a trust fund for donations and management. The Memorial will consist of the designated "Memorial Boundary" area on the map, with the Foundation as the management entity. The Foundation will manage the Memorial, including construction, operation, maintenance, and management. The Memorial will no longer be part of the National Park System if the Foundation fails to comply with laws or maintain the required trust fund. The map of the Memorial will be available for public inspection at National Park Service offices. The Secretary can enter into cooperative agreements for technical assistance. The Secretary can provide technical assistance and enter cooperative agreements with the Foundation for financial support in marketing the Memorial. The Secretary is not authorized to use federal funds for construction, operation, maintenance, or management of the Memorial. A general management plan for the Memorial will be developed by the Secretary in consultation with the Foundation. The Secretary will provide a copy of the completed general management plan for the Memorial to the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate.
